poem:
Title: Are the Blossoms Tired?

Should blossoms tire
of their sweet, whispered tunes -
Sunak's plan burns hot,
unbidden.
A carnation's brittle stem
beneath a government's breeze,
frail against green judgment.

New gas plants,
sighing beneath Britain's grey shroud -
A dance with scepter and cloak,
reshaping shadows.
Future seasons in delicate hands,
yet policy failures cast ghostly echoes –

Do the hyacinths dream
of spring's untainted blue?
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "What does Sunak’s plan for new gas plants mean for UK climate targets? Rishi Sunak’s plan to encourage investment in a string of new gas plants to power the country into the next decade has raised questions over Britain’s future climate ambitions – and the government’s energy policy record. The government’s biggest set of electricity market reforms in over a decade has angered green campaigners who claim that successive policy failures have forced the government". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
